CatDescriptText: Joeann Biggs, housewife, Schenley Heights and Edward Jackson, laborer, Shadyside, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in the Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, June 10, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that the 'Freedom Riders' should accede to Atty. Gen. Robert Kennedy's request for a 'cooling-off' period in their program to test segregation laws of certain Southern states?"  Joeann Biggs' answer reads: "No, I don't think they should.  ONce they're moving, they should continue until there are some real benefits.  If the whites do not want to give us our rights, we Negroes should band together to secure them."  Edward Jackson's answer reads: "They should keep on at what they are doing.  If they stop now, the people down there never would get any peace."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Joeann Biggs wearing light colored collared dress, standing in front of building; Portrait of Edward Jackson wearing polo shirt and hat, standing in front of car, truck and buildings in background
